sentence: Colgate-Palmolive CompanyCL has to its credit a solid history of rewarding shareholders with regular quarterly dividend payouts since 1895.
Since then, the company has paid dividends every quarter, even amid economic crises like the Great Depression of the 1930s, stagflation in the 1970s and the recession of 2008.
Apart from consistent dividend payouts, the company has focused on increasing its dividend rate every year since 2005.
Keeping up with this trend, last week Colgate-Palmolive hiked its quarterly dividend by 3% to 39 cents from the previous payout of 38 cents per share.
Effective second-quarter 2016, this brings the company's annualized dividend to $1.56 per share, currently yielding 2.3%.

The new dividend will be paid on May 16, to shareholders on record as of Apr 22, 2016.

Dividend hikes are frequent among companies with a stable cash position and healthy cash flows.
Recently, the dividend was also raised by 17% to 69 cents by Home Depot Inc. HD , 3% to 37 cents by GameStop Corp. GME and 10% to 15.125 cents by DICK's Sporting Goods Inc. DKS .
A dividend hike not only enhances shareholder returns, but also raises the market value of the stock.
Through dividend increases, companies persuade investors to either buy or hold the scrip instead of selling it.
Colgate's strategy of paying a regular dividend and increasing the same reflects its commitment toward boosting the long-term value for shareholders.
This move also reveals the company's ability to increase earnings and cash flows in the long run, while highlighting its well-defined prospects.

We believe Colgate is an excellent stock from the shareholder perspective given its disciplined capital allocation strategy that focuses on making investments to develop its business, while using the excess cash to enhance shareholder returns through dividend payouts and share buybacks, all thanks to its strong cash generation ability.
In addition to dividends, the company returns value to stockholders through its share repurchase program.
In 2015, the company returned about $3 billion to shareholders, comprising dividend payouts of nearly $1,493 million and share buybacks worth $1,551 million.

This highlights the company's commitment to boosting shareholder returns, even in the face of adverse foreign currency fluctuations and a tough macroeconomic environment that is weighing on its quarterly results.
Colgate's fourth-quarter 2015 earnings beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate by a penny, whereas sales lagged the same for the eleventh straight quarter.
Moreover, both top and bottom lines declined year over year.
Going forward, management expects these headwinds to linger in 2016, in turn posing concerns.
Thus, Colgate retains a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell).
